Introduction

Dumping syndrome is a common complication of bariatric and gastric surgeries (eg, gastric bypass) that alter normal gastrointestinal anatomy and motility.  These changes result in the rapid emptying of hypertonic gastric contents into the small intestine, which provokes a combination of postprandial gastrointestinal symptoms (eg, nausea, diarrhea, abdominal cramping) and vasomotor symptoms (eg, palpitations, diaphoresis).

Pathophysiology and clinical presentation



Normally, food moves through the stomach slowly, ensuring proper digestion.  The pyloric sphincter serves as a barrier and allows only small, properly digested food particles to move to the small intestine.  Surgical removal or bypass of the pyloric sphincter allows hyperosmolar, partially digested contents to enter the small intestine too rapidly, triggering a cascade of abnormal physiologic responses.



Dumping syndrome is categorized as either early or late, based on the timing and etiology of postprandial symptoms.

Early dumping syndrome



Early dumping syndrome occurs within 10-30 minutes of eating and results from the sudden delivery of hypertonic gastric contents into the small bowel.  This creates a strong osmotic gradient, rapidly drawing fluid from the intravascular space into the intestinal lumen, leading to intestinal distension and hypovolemia.  In response, the body activates autonomic (primarily sympathetic) reflexes and releases vasoactive peptides (eg, serotonin, vasoactive intestinal peptide), which contribute to the characteristic vasomotor symptoms, as follows:



  • Excessive intestinal fluid:  Produces abdominal cramps, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and bloating.
  • Autonomic/vasomotor hyperactivity:  Results in flushing, diaphoresis, dizziness, and palpitations.
  • Intravascular volume depletion:  Leads to hypotension and tachycardia.

Late dumping syndrome



Late dumping syndrome (postprandial hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia) typically occurs 2-3 hours after eating a carbohydrate-rich meal.  Rapid delivery of glucose-rich gastric contents to the small intestine causes a spike in blood sugar, followed by an exaggerated insulin response.  Patients develop reactive hypoglycemia, with symptoms including diaphoresis, tremors, palpitations, confusion, dizziness, weakness, and occasional syncope.  This condition often occurs months to years after a bariatric/gastric surgery.

Etiology



Dumping syndrome is often a sequelae of bariatric/gastric surgeries that alter normal gastrointestinal anatomy and motility:



  • Bariatric surgery:  Gastric bypass (eg, Roux-en-Y (
    figure 1
    )).
  • Subtotal or total gastrectomy.
  • Fundoplication.
  • Pyloroplasty.

Differential diagnosis



  • Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth:  Can occur after surgical creation of a blind intestinal loop that promotes bacterial colonization.  It manifests with diarrhea, bloating, nausea, and abdominal cramps.  A postprandial onset of symptoms and vasomotor hyperactivity (eg, diaphoresis) are not typical.
  • Carcinoid syndrome:  Caused by serotonin-secreting tumors and characterized by spontaneous episodes of intense cutaneous flushing (sometimes associated with tachycardia and hypotension) and persistent watery diarrhea.  Symptoms are not typically triggered by meals, and abdominal cramping and vomiting are not characteristic. 
  • Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS):  Marked by abdominal discomfort and altered bowel habits (diarrhea, constipation, or both).  However, this chronic functional gastrointestinal disorder occurs without prior surgery.  In addition, symptoms are not solely post prandial, and autonomic symptoms (eg, tachycardia) are not expected.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of dumping syndrome is primarily clinical, based on characteristic postprandial symptoms and a history of bariatric and/or gastric surgery.  However, additional testing may be useful when the diagnosis is uncertain:



  • Gastric emptying study (gastric scintigraphy):  Serial images track the movement of radiolabeled food at 1, 2, and 4 hours postmeal to determine the percentage of gastric contents emptied over time.  Accelerated emptying supports the diagnosis of dumping syndrome.
  • Oral glucose challenge test:  Glucose load (eg, 50 g) is administered orally after 10 hours of fasting.  Heart rate elevation of â‰¥10/min in the first hour is highly specific for early dumping syndrome.

Management



Most cases of dumping syndrome can be managed successfully with the following dietary modifications:



  • Consume small, frequent meals, and eat slowly.
  • Avoid simple sugars.
  • Increase fiber and protein intake.
  • Drink fluids between, rather than during, meals.


Patients with refractory symptoms may benefit from a trial of pharmacologic therapy:



  • Octreotide:  Somatostatin analogue that slows gastric emptying and reduces gastrointestinal hormone release.
  • Acarbose:  Slows carbohydrate breakdown and absorption in the intestine and helps prevent late dumping.


Surgical intervention (eg, pyloric reconstruction) is rarely needed and reserved only for patients with recalcitrant symptoms despite conservative management.

Prognosis



With dietary management (Â± medication), most patients experience significant symptom relief, and symptoms of dumping syndrome usually diminish over time.
